proof:
Proof. For any given set $S$ with size $\xi n \le |S| \le (1-\xi)|S|$, $\text{degg}(S)$ is a sum of independent $2\text{Bin}(\binom{|S|}{2}, d/n)$ and $\text{Bin}(|S|(n-|S|), d/n)$ random variables, corresponding to inner edges, and edges going outside of $S$ respectively.

First we bound $P(2\text{Bin}(\binom{|S|}{2}, d/n) < (1-\varepsilon)d|S|)$. By Chernoff, for $n$ large enough so that $(1-\varepsilon)/(|S|-1) < \varepsilon/2$ and $1/n < \xi/2$, this is at most $\exp\{-\frac{d\varepsilon^2\xi^2 n}{32}\}$.

Then for the proportion of the degree corresponding to the edges of going from $S$ to $\bar{S}$, this is $\sim \text{Bin}(|S|(n-|S|), d/n)$, and by Chernoff $P(\text{Bin}(|S|(n-|S|), d/n) < (1-\varepsilon)\frac{d|S|(n-|S|)}{n}) \le \exp\{-\frac{d\varepsilon^2\xi^2 n}{2}\}$.

Hence by union bound, there is such a set with average degree $< (1-\varepsilon)dn$ with probability at most $\exp\{-d\varepsilon^2\xi^2n/2\} + \exp\{-d\varepsilon^2\xi^2n/32\}$. There are at most $2^n$ such sets $S$, thus by another union bound and by the condition on $d$, we obtain that the probability of a large set of small average degree existing is at most $\exp\{-\Omega(n)\} = o(1)$.
